questions.question: Which of the following diseases is not included under the program mentioned in the logo?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Leprosy Explanation: This image shows the National Vector-Born Disease Control Program (NVBDCP). Leprosy is included under the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP). National vector-borne disease control program (NVBDCP): Launched: 2002. Includes all vector-borne diseases: Vector Disease Anopheles Malaria Aedes Dengue & chikungunya Culex Japanese encephalitis: Culex quinquefasciatus/ Culex fatigans Filariasis: Culex tritaeniorhynchus, Culex vishnui Sandfly Kala-azar

questions.question: All of the following are objectives of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) except?

options.A: To reduce annual parasite incidence < 1/1000 population
options.B: To reduce annual blood examination rate < 10%
options.C: To control and prevent outbreaks of dengue and chikungunya.
options.D: To eliminate kala-azar, lymphatic filariasis and Malaria

questions.explanation: parasite incidence (API) < 1/1000 population - to check effectiveness of preventive interventions (OPTION A) To increase annual blood examination rate > 10% - to check operational efficiency (OPTION B) To eliminate malaria by 2030 To eliminate kala-azar and lymphatic filariasis as soon as possible (OPTION D) Reduce morbidity and mortality due to dengue and chikungunya. (OPTION C) Treatment, prevention, control and surveillance of the six vector-borne diseases. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 472-473

questions.question: Which of the following methods are classified as anti-larval techniques for mosquito control? Malathion Bacillus thuringiensis Temephos Gambusia affinis
questions.explanation: control Biological control Yield permanent results and source reduction. E.g. Filling drains and ditches. Levelling of ground. Proper drainage of breeding areas. Intermittent irrigation. Changing water alkalinity. Using larvicides E.g. 1. Physical: MLO (Mosquito larvicidal oil): 200L/hectare 2. Chemical: Paris green (stomach poison) Temephos (Abate): 200L/hectare 3. IGR (insect growth regulators): Inhibit chitin formation, moulding and adult maturation. Pyriproxyfen and Diflubenzuron Larvivorous Fishes: 1. Gambusia and Poecilia fish 2. Bacillus thuringiensis (used in polluted waters) 3. Toxorhynchites splendens (predator mosquito for Aedes and Anopheles) ANTI-ADULT MEASURES: 2 types of sprays are used: Space sprays : Only one time spray done ; Achieved through fogging Indoor residual sprays: Done at regular intervals Chemicals used in sprays: Malathion - Alternative to DDT ; Contact poison ; Usually sprayed every 3 months. DDT - Residual action : 5-7 months ; Contact poison Pyrethroid - like deltamethrin , cyfluthrin Indoor residual sprays and space sprays using malathion (for cases refractory to DDT) and DDT (Contact neurotoxic) are anti-adult measures (Option A). Long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLINs) protect individuals from adult mosquito bites (Option C). Chemical control using lemon grass, neem oil and diethyl toluamide are used as personal protective measures (Option D). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 477-479

questions.question: Among different states, Madhya Pradesh has an Annual Parasite Incidence (API) of less than 1, but some districts have an API greater than 1. Which of the following options correctly matches its categorisation? 1. Category 0 a. Pre-elimination phase 2. Category 1 b. Prevention of re-establishment phase. 3. Category 2 c. Intensified control phase 4. Category 3 d. Elimination phase
questions.explanation: Category API Phase Category 0 0 Prevention of re-establishment/ resurgence Category 1 <1, all districts <1 Elimination phase Category 2 <1 but some districts >1 Pre-elimination phase Category 3 >1 Intensified control phase National framework for malaria elimination in India(2016-2030): Targets: Elimination of malaria (zero indigenous cases) by 2030 Prevention of re-establishment of malaria in states who have achieved elimination level (API value is based on NFME) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 474-479

questions.question: In areas with an API greater than 2, what is the spray of choice for vector control if the vector is refractory to DDT?

options.A: Two rounds of DDT six weekly during the transmission season
options.B: Three rounds of malathion six weekly during the transmission season
options.C: A single round of deltamethrin during the transmission season

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Three rounds of malathion six weekly during the transmission season refractory to DDT (Option A). Malathion 25% Synthetic pyrethroids: Deltamethrin and Cyfluthrin IRS with insecticides when API >2 : Note: Long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLIN) covers the population living in areas where API > 5. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 474-479

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about Long-Lasting Insecticidal Nets (LLINs)?

options.A: Need to be re-treated with insecticide every six months to remain effective.
options.B: Provide insecticidal action against mosquitoes only.
options.D: Can be washed without losing their insecticidal properties for up to 3 years.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Can be washed without losing their insecticidal properties for up to 3 years. to retain their effectiveness for an extended period, typically up to 3 years , even after repeated washing. They are a critical tool in NVBDCP to fight against mosquito-borne diseases. Purpose: Dual action provides a physical barrier against mosquito bites while also delivering insecticidal action. Insecticides Used: Typically synthetic pyrethroids: Permethrin Deltamethrin Durability: Effective for up to 3 years. Material and Mesh Size: Made from polyester or polyethene. Mesh size: around 156 holes per square inch. Benefits: Protection Against Mosquito Bites Reduction in Malaria Incidence Cost-Effective Easy to Use Long-lasting activity Low toxicity to humans and animals Challenges: Insecticide Resistance Distribution and Coverage Maintenance Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page.475 https://ncvbdc.mohfw.gov.in/WriteReadData/l892s/Guidelines-for-ITNS-LLINS.pdf https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9562956/

questions.question: Which of the following are a part of the organization of NVBDCP? 1. Multipurpose Workers (MPWs) 2. District Malaria Officer 3. Directorate General of Health Services 4. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. 1, 2, 3, and 4 Explanation: The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is a comprehensive program under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India. Organizational Structure of NVBDCP 1. National Level: Directorate General of Health Services (DGHS): Director General: Oversees all health programs, including NVBDCP. 2. State Level: State Health Department: State Program Officer (SPO) State Surveillance Officer (SSO) 3. District Level: (District Health Department) District Malaria Officer (DMO) or District Vector Borne Disease Control Officer (DVBDCO). 4. Primary Health Center (PHC) Level: Medical Officer In-Charge Multipurpose Workers (MPWs): Conducting field activities such as spraying insecticides and distributing LLINs. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) Workers: Engaging in community outreach, education, and basic healthcare services. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page.472,473 https://ncvbdc.mohfw.gov.in/WriteReadData/l892s/2163560901531913328.pdf https://ncvbdc.mohfw.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=1&sublinkid=5885&lid=3964

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Enhanced Malaria Control programme is incorrect? residual spraying.

options.A: Aims to completely eradicate malaria globally by 2025.
options.B: The programme integrates vector control measures such as insecticide-treated nets and indoor
options.C: The programme is being aided by the World Bank.
options.D: Primarily targets rural and urban areas where malaria transmission rates are highest.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Aims to completely eradicate malaria globally by 2025. Explanation: The enhanced malaria control project aims to eradicate malaria globally by 2030. Enhanced Malaria Control (EMC) Project: Refers to a comprehensive approach to combating malaria through various strategies and interventions. Initiated by National governments collaborating with international organisations (e.g., WHO, NGOs like Malaria Consortium) and donor agencies (e.g., Global Fund). Indian Scenario: The World Bank-aided Enhanced Malaria Control Project (EMCP) was implemented in the tribal areas of 100 high malaria burden districts of 8 states , viz., Andhra Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Gujarat, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Orissa and Rajasthan. The programme focuses on both rural and urban areas where malaria transmission occurs. Objectives and Goals: Reduce Malaria Transmission: This strategy focuses on both rural and urban areas where malaria transmission occurs by implementing effective vector control (e.g., bed nets and indoor spraying). Improve Case Management: Ensure prompt diagnosis and treatment. Enhance Surveillance and Monitoring: Strengthen systems to track cases. Community Engagement: Educate and involve communities in prevention and treatment. Achieve Sustainable Results: Work towards sustained reduction and, where possible, elimination of malaria. Reference: https://ncvbdc.mohfw.gov.in/WriteReadData/l892s/Strategic-Action-Plan-Malaria-2012-17-Co.pdf

questions.question: A 28-year-old traveller returning from a malaria-endemic region presents with high fever, chills, and sweating. A physician orders thick and thin blood smears as part of the diagnostic workup for malaria. What is the primary purpose of the thin smear in malaria diagnosis?

options.A: To detect the presence of malaria parasites.
options.B: To determine the species of malaria parasite.
options.C: To assess the degree of anaemia.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) To determine the species of malaria parasite. Explanation: The Jaswantsingh Bhattacharya (J.B.) stain is a modified Romanowsky stain used as an alternative to Giemsa stain for preparing thick and thin blood smears in malaria diagnosis. Thin Smear is used primarily to identify and differentiate the species of Plasmodium. It allows for better visualisation of the malaria parasites and their stages, aiding in accurate species identification. This information is crucial for appropriate treatment and management of the patient. Thick smear used for Detection of Parasites: Thick smear microscopy is particularly useful for detecting the presence of malaria parasites in a sample. Thick smears involve a higher concentration of blood cells and are more sensitive in detecting low levels of parasitemia. Acridine orange staining for malaria detection JSB stain is used for preparation of thick and thin smears Quantification of Parasites: Thick smears allow for the estimation of the parasite load or density, which is crucial in determining the severity of the infection and monitoring the response to treatment. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): The technique is a rapid, sensitive method for diagnosing malaria. It utilizes fluorescent dyes like acridine orange to stain parasite DNA in blood samples, which are then examined under an epifluorescent microscope. While it enhances sensitivity for P. falciparum , it is less effective for non-falciparum species and suffers from reduced specificity due to leukocyte DNA staining. The method is highly sensitive at low parasitemia but requires specialized, costly equipment and doesn't provide species identification or parasite quantification. Reference: Paniker Parasitology (8th edition) Page. 81 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2688806/#:~:text=QBC%20technique,numbers%20of%20parasites.

questions.question: Which principle is utilised in the Optimal test within the NVBDCP?

options.A: Detects the HRP2 antigen produced by Plasmodium falciparum.
options.C: Detects the pLDH enzyme produced by live parasites.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Detects the pLDH enzyme produced by live parasites Explanation: The pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase) test is used as the Optimal test among other Rapid Diagnostics Test (RDT) available for several reasons: Detection of all Plasmodium species and the ability to differentiate between species like P. falciparum and P. vivax. Indicator of Active Infection. Rapid and efficient diagnosis; provides results within 15-20 minutes. Non-Invasiveness and Ease of Use. Cost-Effectiveness. Type of RDT Target Principle Use Limitations HRP2 Test P. falciparum Detects the HRP2 antigen produced by Plasmodium falciparum Commonly used in areas with predominant Plasmodium falciparum 1. Does not detect non-falciparum species. 2. HRP-2 can persist in blood for weeks after the infection, which may lead to false-positives. pLDH Test All Plasmodium species (species-specific variations) Detects the pLDH enzyme produced by live parasites 1. Identifies active infections 2. Can differentiate between species like P. falciparum and P. vivax pLDH degrades rapidly, possibly missing low-level or early-stage infections Aldolase Test All Plasmodium species Detects the aldolase enzyme common to all Plasmodium species Identifies infections caused by any malaria parasite Less sensitive and specific compared to HRP2 and pLDH tests Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC124834/ Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page.306

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding “link workers” in malaria control?

options.A: 1 per 500 people involved in the active detection of P. vivax
options.B: 1 per 2000 people involved in the active detection of P. falciparum
options.C: 1 per 500 people involved in active detection of P. falciparum
options.D: 1 per 2000 people involved in active detection of P. vivax

questions.explanation: There will be 1 link worker per 2000 people. Other active detection strategies: Preparing malarial smears once every 2 weeks at sub-centers by multipurpose male workers.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents with intermittent fever, chills, and sweats. He recently returned from a trip to a malaria-endemic region. Laboratory tests confirm the diagnosis of Plasmodium vivax malaria. What is the drug of choice for the treatment of Plasmodium vivax malaria?
questions.explanation: malaria: Chloroquine (25 mg/kg) divided dose for 3 days. Day 1: 10 mg/kg. Day 2: 10 mg/kg. Day 3: 5 mg/kg. Primaquine 0.25 mg/kg for 14 days. Note: Primaquine is contraindicated in G6PD deficiency Pregnancy Infants P.vivax and P.ovale infections have “hypnozoites,” which remain dormant in the liver and are released into the bloodstream. Primaquine is given to eradicate these hypnozoites. Primaquine has a multi-dose regime for killing hypnozoites (Radical cure) Tafenoquine is a single-dose radical cure (hypnozoite killing) for vivax malaria Treatment of malaria (under NVBDCP): Types of malaria DOC DOC in pregnancy P.Vivax Chloroquine Chloroquine P.falciparum ACT Quinine Mixed ACT Quinine Complicated /severe/cerebral malaria IV Artesunate IV Artesunate Chemoprophylaxis: Short term: Travelling for <6 weeks: Doxycycline(DOC) 100 mg daily Started 1-2 days before travel, the dose has to be continued for 4 weeks post travel. Long term: Travelling for > 6 weeks: Mefloquine (DOC) 250 mg weekly Started 2-3 weeks before travel, the dose has to be continued for 4 weeks post travel Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pages 307,308

questions.question: A 10-year-old child from Assam who weighs 32 kg is diagnosed with falciparum malaria. What is the recommended dose of Artemether and Lumefantrine for this child respectively?
questions.explanation: of treatment are followed for falciparum malarial infection. 1) ACT-AL: The combination of ACT-AL (artemether & lumefantrine) is recommended according to the patient's age and weight. The child given in this scenario falls in the third category (60 mg/360 mg). 5-14 kg/5 months to 3 years 15-24 kg/3 to 8 years 25-34 kg/9 to 14 years > 34 kg/> 14 years Total dose of ACT-AL 20mg/120mg BD x 3 days 40mg/240mg BD x 3 days 60mg/360mg BD for 3 days 80mg/480mg BD x 3 days Pack size No. of tablets in the packing 6 12 18 24 Give 1 tablet BD x 3 days 2 tablets BD x 3 days 3 tablets BD x 3 days 4 tablets BD x 3 days Colour of the pack Yellow Green Red White 2) Primaquine : 0.75mg/kg on day 2. Contraindications about ACT-AL therapy: 1st trimester of pregnancy. Children of age < 5 years. Body weight < 5kg. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 310

questions.question: A patient was admitted with severe fever, neck stiffness, photophobia and confusion. Lumbar puncture done was unremarkable but rapid diagnostic test done shows falciparum malarial infection. All of the following drugs can be used in this patient except?
questions.explanation: malaria due to P. falciparum infection and mefloquine should not be used in the same because of the neuropsychiatric complications associated with it, which is termed CNS toxicity syndrome. Treatment of severe/complicated malaria: Initial parenteral treatment (48 hours) Follow-up treatment Quinine Loading dose: 20 mg/kg Maintenance dose : 10 mg/kg TDS Quinine 10 mg/kg TDS + Doxycycline 3 mg/kg (or) Clindamycin 10 mg/kg (if pregnant / children < 8 years) Total treatment duration: 7 days Artesunate : 2.4 mg/kg loading dose, then at 12th and 24th hour followed by once a day. Artemether : Loading dose of 3.2 mg/kg; maintenance dose of 1.6 mg/kg per day. Arteether : 150 mg per day for 3 days. ACT therapy North-eastern states: Age & weight adjusted ACT-AL for 3 days + primaquine on second day. Other states: ACT-SP (sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine) for 3 days + primaquine on second day. Contraindications of mefloquine: History of Convulsions. Neuropsychiatric illness. Cardiac pathologies. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Pages 311,312,313

questions.question: A 30-year-old man is planning a 3-month trip to a malaria-endemic area in Sub-Saharan Africa. He visits his healthcare provider to discuss options for malaria prophylaxis. Considering the need for long-term prophylaxis, which of the following is the most appropriate drug of choice?

options.A: Chloroquine 300 mg once a week, on the same day each week.
options.B: Proguanil 100 mg, 2 tablets once a day.
options.C: Mefloquine 250 mg, one tablet once a week, on the same day each week.
options.D: Mefloquine 250 mg, one tablet once a day each week

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Mefloquine 250 mg, one tablet once a week, on the same day each week. once a week, on the same day each week. Chemoprophylaxis of malaria: Short-term prophylaxis Long-term prophylaxis Duration of Rx < 6 weeks > 6 weeks DOC Doxycycline 100 mg daily Mefloquine 250 mg weekly Prophylaxis period Before travel 1-2 days 2-3 weeks After travel 4 weeks 4 weeks Contraindications of mefloquine: History of convulsions. Neuropsychiatric illness. Cardiac conditions. Other drugs for short-term prophylaxis: Chloroquine: 100 mg or 150 mg tablets. 300 mg (3 tablets of 100 mg or 2 tablets of 150 mg), once a week, on the same day each week. (Or) One tablet of 100 mg daily for 6 days per week. Proguanil: 200 mg, 2 tablets once a day. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pages 312,313
